title: China Development Bank provides $4.1 billion loan Galkynysh Gas Field Phase II Project (Linked to Project ID#40393 and #43168)
description: In April 2011, China Development Bank signed an loan-for-gas framework agreement with Turkmengaz (the national natural gas company of Turkmenistan) for Phase 2 of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project (also known as South Yolotan–Osman Field Project or the Ioujno-Elotenshoie Gas Field Project).Then, in September 2013, China Development Bank and Turkmengaz signed a $4.1 billion loan agreement for this project. The CDB loan is reportedly secured by natural gas exports to China. Turkmengaz will use the revenue it earns from a supply contract for natural gas as collateral for the loan. The loan will be disbursed over 3 years, and in return Turkmengaz will reportedly supply natural gas to China for 10 years.CNPC is the contractor responsible for project implementation. The purpose of phase II of this project was to build facilities at the Galkynysh Gas Field that will process 30 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year. The project entered implementation on May 8, 2014.Staff Note: This project is part of the umbrella project captured in project #43168 and it is considered to be part of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). Phase I of the Galkynysh Gas Field is captured in #40393.

location_details: The Galkynysh Gas Field, formerly known as Iolotan gas field or South Yolotan – Osman field, is a large natural gas field near Ýolöten in Mary Province

title: China Exim Bank loans 400 million RMB to Turkmenneft for the supply of oil, gas equipment, and tubular goods
description: The China Exim Bank implemented a 400 million RMB credit to supply Turkmenneft for the supply of oil, gas equipment, and tubular goods. As of 2011, the project was still being implemented. STAFF_NOTE: The original commitment year of the loan is unclear, but 2011 is the first found source that lists the project.

title: Chinese Government provides a 2 million USD interest-free loan to Turkmenistan for reconstruction of Ashgabat Silk Factory
description: The Chinese Government provided a 2 million USD interest-free loan for the reconstruction of Ashgabat Silk Factory, the oldest silk production enterprise in Turkmenistan (also known as the Ashkhabad Filature). The loan was provided in 2002, 2003, or 2004. The factory, built during Soviet rule, had outdated technology, incomplete production processes, and a low production level before the project began. Shanxi Zhongxu International Trade Industrial Co., Ltd. implemented the project. The project was completed in a ceremony attended by President of Turkmenistan Saparmurat Niyazov and Ambassador Lu Guicheng on February 12, 2004.STAFF_NOTE: There are several project titles in Chinese, including 2个缫丝厂 (see "china_data_032010[1].xlsx") and 中国援土阿什哈巴德缫丝厂 (see "土库曼斯坦--中国对外开放30周年回顾展"). Further loan details are unknown; it is not clear which year this loan was provided, but it was between 2002 and 2004. So AidData chose the 2002, the earliest one, as the commitment year, and "Year uncertain" box was checked. Ashgabat is also known as "Ashkhabad".
sources: https://www.files.ethz.ch/isn/105663/CEFQ200805.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.jica.go.jp/jica-ri/IFIC_and_JBICI-Studies/jica-ri/english/publication/archives/jbic/report/working/pdf/wp27_e.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://tm.mofcom.gov.cn/sys/print.shtml?/ztdy/200408/20040800264023, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/x8xdpvxmghaq3hi/china_data_032010%5B1%5D.xlsx?dl=0, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://www.dropbox.com/s/77e5y0ofv1zfphk/%E5%9C%9F%E5%BA%93%E6%9B%BC%E6%96%AF%E5%9D%A6--%E4%B8%AD%E5%9B%BD%E5%AF%B9%E5%A4%96%E5%BC%80%E6%94%BE30%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E5%9B%9E%E9%A1%BE%E5%B1%95.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/c0so9pwet0v5tnt/Turkmenistan%20-%20Retrospective%20of%20the%2030th%20Anniversary%20of%20China%27s%20Opening%20to%20the%20Outside%20World.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://tm.mofcom.gov.cn/article/ztdy/200408/20040800264023.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://tm.mofcom.gov.cn/article/todayheader/201406/20140600641656.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.yarnsandfibers.com/news/textile-news/turkmenistan-spinning-new-life-into-its-silk-industry/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://tm.mofcom.gov.cn/sys/print.shtml?/ddfg/200608/20060802980703, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Development Bank provides $3 billion loan for Galkynysh (South Yolotan–Osman) Gas Field Phase I Project (Linked to Project ID#41905 and #43168)
description: On June 25, 2009, China Development Bank signed a $3 billion loan agreement with Turkmengaz (the national natural gas company of Turkmenistan) for Phase 1 of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project (also known as South Yolotan–Osman Field Project). The loan is secured by natural gas exports to China.This loan was given to help develop the Galkynysh Gas Field (also known as South Yolotan–Osman Field) while Turkmenistan will supply China with up to 40 billion cubic meters/year of gas for 30 years. They include a supplementary agreement covering CNPC's exploration and production activities at Bagitiyarlik, where the company has a license to produce up to 30 Bcm/year, and a separate contract under which state-owned Turkmengaz will deliver 10 Bcm/year to CNPC. The fact that Turkmengaz and CNPC signed a contract for the delivery of an additional 10 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year at the same time that the loan agreement was finalized suggests that Turkmengaz will use the revenue it earns from this supply contract for natural gas as collateral for the loan.  Few other details about the terms of the loan, including the price at which the natural gas is sold to CNPC, are publicly available.The first phase of the project began on February 28, 2011 and it was completed on September 4, 2013.   Then, in April 2013, China signed an additional $4.1 billion loan agreement with the Government of Turkmenistan for the second phase of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project. The loan will be disbursed over 3 years, and in return Turkmenistan will reportedly supply natural gas to China for 10 years (see project ID #41905).Staff Note: The Phase 1 of the Galkynysh Gas Field project is part of the umbrella project captured in project #43168.

title: China EXIM Bank Loans 200 million yuan to Turkmengaz for supply of oil and gas equipment and pipe products
description: In 2011, China's EXIM Bank continued to implement a loan of 200 million yuan to Turkmengaz. The commitment year of this loan is unclear. Turkmengaz will use the funds to purchase oil, gas, and pipeline equipment for their operations. STAFF_NOTE: Use the most current Turkmenistan's country report in the resources - previous researcher used the 2011 annual report, which mistakenly reported the amount as 200 billion yuan.

title: China provides an RMB 10 million grant for the transformation of the sericulture farms in Turkmenistan
description: In 1999 and 2000, Chinese government provided an RMB 10 million free assistance to the Turkmenistan Ministry of Textile Industry for the comprehensively transformation of the sericulture farms in Turkmenistan. Jiangsu International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation (also known as China Jiangsu International) provided sericulture equipment and materials. After the transformation, the annual output of the silkworm breeding farm in Turkmenistan reached 150,000 boxes annually.STAFF_NOTE: Chinese title of the implementation company is 中国江苏国际经济技术合作集团有限公司.

title: China grants Turkmenistan 15 million RMB for mechanical plant (Linked to project #40169)
description: On Dec. 26, 2003, State officials of China and Turkmenistan signed an agreement for a grant of 15 million RMB (1.8 million USD) and an interest-free credit of 30 million USD (see project #40169). The grant was to be used by Turkmengaz to purchase equipment and spare parts for its repair mechanical plant. Current project status is unknown. More info can be found at https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=TRENDE0020150507eb57001e3&cat=a&ep=ASE
